metadata.title: Prolonged Seizure Activity - Status Epilepticus with Hypoglycemia
learning_objectives: Identify hypoglycemia as treatable cause of seizures
Manage airway during active seizure without dangerous interventions
Recognize treatment failure and escalate appropriately
Balance seizure control with respiratory depression risk
Demonstrate critical thinking: treat causes not just symptoms

changelog.v2.0_final_enhanced: Added Layer Two cognitive training (interactive challenge points with full rubrics, critical decision points). Expanded medication formulary to 30+ drugs organized by harm level. Enhanced pharmacokinetics for all primary medications. Added cognitive coach questioning system. Corrected no-treatment progression timing to 3/5/10 min. Added treatment sequence rubrics and AAR teaching structure. Complete parity with STEMI and Asthma enhanced blueprints.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Patient having continuous seizure activity, shaking all over and unresponsive. Boyfriend reports seizure has been ongoing for several minutes without stopping. Patient has known epilepsy but boyfriend states her seizures normally stop after a minute or two. She's on the floor, boyfriend moved furniture away for safety.

scene_description.location: Bedroom, patient on floor next to bed
scene_description.safety: Scene safe, boyfriend moved furniture away from patient
scene_description.access: 2nd floor, narrow staircase, boyfriend can help with carry
scene_description.bystanders: Boyfriend present, very distressed but trying to help, knows patient's history

patient_profile.name: Andrea
patient_profile.personality: During seizure: unresponsive. Post-seizure: confused, gradually recovers, anxious about what happened

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find a young woman lying on her side on the bedroom floor, actively seizing. Her body is rigid and shaking rhythmically with violent jerking movements of her arms and legs. Her eyes are rolled back and her jaw is clenched tight. You can hear gurgling sounds from her airway with saliva visible at her mouth. Her lips appear bluish. The seizure activity continues as you approach. Her boyfriend is kneeling nearby, visibly distressed.
initial.appearance: Active tonic-clonic seizure, whole body convulsing, cyanotic, eyes rolled back, jaw clenched, incontinent of urine, copious secretions
initial.clinical_note: STATUS EPILEPTICUS - seizure >5 minutes is medical emergency. Patient is hypoxic (SpO2 88%) from inadequate ventilation during seizure. CRITICAL: Check glucose immediately - hypoglycemia (1.8 mmol/L) is the underlying CAUSE and is immediately reversible with glucose. Position patient on side, protect airway, suction secretions, prepare for benzodiazepine if seizure continues after glucose. High risk of brain damage if seizure continues >30 minutes total. Already 6-7 minutes into seizure per boyfriend.

improving.student_sees: The violent shaking has stopped. The patient is now lying still on her side, breathing deeply but irregularly. Her eyes are closed, and she's unresponsive when you call her name, but she's no longer seizing. Her color is improving - the cyanosis is resolving and her lips are becoming pink again. The boyfriend looks relieved but worried. 'Is she going to be okay?' After about 2-3 minutes, you notice her eyelids flutter. She makes a small groaning sound. Her breathing is becoming more regular. She's in the postictal state - deeply sleepy but starting to show signs of gradual recovery.
improving.appearance: Seizure terminated, postictal state, unresponsive but breathing adequately, color improving, gradual emergence
improving.clinical_note: Seizure successfully terminated with appropriate treatment (glucose + benzodiazepine if given). Patient in postictal phase - this is NORMAL. GCS will gradually improve from 6-7 → 10-12 → 14-15 over next 10-20 minutes. Continue monitoring closely. Recheck glucose to ensure it's rising (target >4.0 mmol/L). Risk of re-seizure if hypoglycemia persists or benzodiazepine wears off before glucose corrected. Transport for evaluation - first-time status epilepticus in known epileptic needs investigation of why it happened (likely insulin without food).

deteriorating.student_sees: Just as you think the seizure has stopped and the patient is starting to recover, her body suddenly goes rigid again. Her arms stiffen at her sides, her back arches. Then the rhythmic jerking starts again - another seizure. The boyfriend gasps. 'No! Not again!' Her SpO2 is dropping again as she seizes. This is her second seizure without regaining consciousness between them. Her color is deteriorating, lips becoming dusky again. The gurgling sound returns as more secretions pool in her airway.
deteriorating.appearance: Second seizure begun, no recovery between seizures, cyanosis returning, secretions, recurrent status epilepticus
deteriorating.clinical_note: RECURRENT SEIZURE - treatment failure. Possibilities: (1) Hypoglycemia not corrected (didn't give glucose or gave insufficient amount), (2) Benzodiazepine dose inadequate (gave 5mg instead of 10mg), (3) Benzodiazepine wearing off before underlying cause treated. Patient remains in status epilepticus. Need immediate intervention: Give glucose if not given, give second dose benzodiazepine (10mg IV, max 20mg total prehospital), manage airway aggressively. Risk of permanent brain damage increasing with each passing minute.

critical.student_sees: The patient is no longer seizing, but this is not good news - she's stopped breathing adequately. Her respiratory rate is slow, shallow, barely moving air. Her SpO2 has dropped to 75%. Her lips and face are deeply cyanotic. She's completely unresponsive - GCS 3. This is either respiratory failure from prolonged seizure activity and metabolic exhaustion, or respiratory depression from excessive benzodiazepine dosing, or both. You need to ventilate her NOW with a bag-valve-mask. The boyfriend is screaming. 'What's happening?! Help her!'
critical.appearance: Not actively seizing but in respiratory failure, barely breathing, deeply cyanotic, GCS 3, pre-arrest state
critical.clinical_note: RESPIRATORY FAILURE - either from: (1) Prolonged seizure causing metabolic exhaustion and hypoxic brain injury, OR (2) Excessive benzodiazepine causing respiratory depression, OR (3) Combination. Immediate BVM ventilation required. High risk of cardiac arrest if not ventilated. If hypoglycemia still not corrected, patient will remain unconscious and may re-seize. Emergency transport with pre-hospital notification. Prognosis guarded - prolonged status epilepticus causes permanent neurological damage. Time from seizure onset to termination is critical prognostic factor.

glucose_40_percent.indication: Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <3.5 mmol/L), altered mental status with suspected hypoglycemia, seizures from hypoglycemia
glucose_40_percent.mechanism: Rapidly increases blood glucose concentration, providing substrate for cellular metabolism. Brain requires continuous glucose supply - cannot store glucose. Hypoglycemia causes neuronal dysfunction → altered mental status, seizures, coma.

dosing.adult_unconscious_seizure: 50ml IV (20g glucose) - larger dose for severe hypoglycemia
dosing.administration: IV push over 1-3 minutes. MUST flush with saline - concentrated solution irritates veins
dosing.repeat_dosing: Recheck glucose in 5-10 minutes. Repeat if glucose <4.0 mmol/L

pharmacokinetics.note: Effect temporary - patient needs food after waking or glucose will drop again. In diabetics on long-acting insulin, may need repeated dosing or IV infusion

relative: hyperglycemia (but check glucose first - don't assume)

side_effects: Extravasation causes tissue necrosis (ensure good IV)
warnings: ALWAYS check glucose before giving - don't assume patient is hypoglycemic
ALWAYS flush with saline after - concentrated solution
If no IV access, can give glucagon 1mg IM (slower, less reliable)
Patient may vomit as they wake up - have suction ready, position on side

vital_changes.seizure_activity: Terminates within 2-4 minutes after glucose given
vital_changes.GCS: Improves to 6-7 initially (postictal), then gradually to 14-15 over 10-20 min

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: Initially unconscious. After 3-5 minutes: confused groaning, 'Wha... what happened? Where am I?' After 10 minutes: 'Oh no... did I have a seizure? I'm so embarrassed.' May not remember events. Ask: 'Did I eat today?' Boyfriend: 'No, you said you felt sick yesterday and didn't eat much.'
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Glucose TREATS THE CAUSE of seizure - hypoglycemia. Seizure stops because brain metabolism normalized. This is ideal treatment - faster and safer than benzodiazepine alone. Patient will be confused (postictal state) but will gradually wake up as glucose effect continues. If seizure stops after glucose alone, this proves hypoglycemia was the cause. Patient still needs benzodiazepine if seizure continues after glucose or if glucose normal.
scenario_specific_response.timing_critical: Should check glucose within 60 seconds and give within 2 minutes if low. Faster glucose = faster seizure termination = less brain damage.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients, especially diabetics. Hypoglycemia is REVERSIBLE cause - treating it stops seizure by correcting underlying problem. Giving benzodiazepine without checking glucose misses the cause. Sequence: (1) Protect airway/oxygen, (2) Check glucose immediately, (3) Give glucose if <3.5, (4) Give benzo if seizure continues after glucose or if glucose normal. In this scenario, glucose IS the treatment - benzodiazepine is backup.

diazepam.indication: Status epilepticus, prolonged seizures (>5 min), seizure clusters, acute anxiety, muscle spasms, alcohol withdrawal
diazepam.mechanism: Enhances GABA (inhibitory neurotransmitter) activity in brain, suppressing excessive neuronal firing. Raises seizure threshold, terminates seizure activity.

dosing.adult_status_epilepticus: 10mg IV slow push (5mg/min), may repeat 10mg after 5-10 minutes if seizure continues

warnings: RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION is major risk - have BVM ready, monitor RR closely
Give IV dose SLOWLY over 2-3 minutes (5mg/min max) - rapid push causes apnea
Wait 5-10 minutes before second dose to assess first dose effect
If no IV access, PR (rectal) route is acceptable alternative
Critical balance: enough to stop seizure vs risk of respiratory depression
Flush IV line after - prevents drug precipitation

scenario_specific_response.when_to_give: IF seizure continues after glucose given, OR if glucose is normal (>3.5)

vital_changes.GCS: Remains low initially (6-7) due to postictal state + drug effect, gradually improves
vital_changes.SpO2: Improves as seizure stops (if not over-dosed)

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: Patient unconscious during administration. After seizure stops and 5-10 minutes pass: confused groaning, 'Where am I? What happened?' More drowsy than if glucose alone used.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Terminates seizure by suppressing neuronal excitability. Effective but doesn't treat underlying cause. Patient will be drowsy/confused from combination of postictal state + drug effect. If hypoglycemia not corrected, seizure may recur when benzodiazepine wears off. Respiratory depression risk increases with dose - 10mg usually safe, 20mg higher risk, >20mg dangerous.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Diazepam is PRIMARY treatment for status epilepticus IF no reversible cause found. BUT - always check glucose FIRST. Sequence: (1) Check glucose, (2) Give glucose if <3.5, (3) Give diazepam if seizure continues or if glucose normal. Dosing: 10mg IV first, wait 5-10 min, repeat 10mg if needed (max 20mg prehospital). NEVER give all 20mg at once - causes dangerous respiratory depression. The critical skill is THINKING: 'Why is this patient seizing?' not just reflexively giving diazepam.

midazolam.indication: Status epilepticus (alternative to diazepam), sedation for procedures, anxiety
midazolam.mechanism: GABA agonist, suppresses seizure activity. Faster onset but shorter duration than diazepam.

dosing.adult_status_epilepticus_im: 10mg IM (if no IV access - very effective)

warnings: Shorter duration than diazepam - may need repeat dosing
IM route highly effective if no IV access
Same respiratory depression risk as diazepam

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Equally effective as diazepam for status epilepticus. Advantage: IM route very effective if no IV access. Shorter duration means less prolonged sedation but may need repeat dose. Same principle: check glucose first.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Midazolam is excellent alternative to diazepam, especially if no IV access (10mg IM). Same rules apply: check glucose FIRST. Shorter duration than diazepam is both advantage (less prolonged sedation) and disadvantage (may need repeat).

delivery_options.non_rebreather_mask: 15 L/min - best for severe hypoxia during seizure
delivery_options.bvm_if_inadequate: If patient not breathing adequately during or after seizure
delivery_options.nasal_cannula_after: 2-6 L/min after seizure stops and breathing adequate

warnings: During active seizure, patient's breathing is inadequate - needs high-flow O2
Position airway properly - on side, suction secretions
Don't force oral airway during active seizure with clenched jaw

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Improves oxygenation during seizure. Essential supportive care. Patient seizing cannot ventilate adequately - needs supplemental oxygen. As seizure stops and breathing improves, SpO2 will rise further.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Oxygen is critical during seizures - patient cannot breathe adequately while convulsing. SpO2 88% = severe hypoxia. Apply high-flow O2 immediately. This is supportive care while you treat underlying cause (glucose) and stop seizure (benzodiazepine if needed).

normal_saline.indication: IV access maintenance, medication dilution, volume resuscitation if needed

dosing.iv_lock: Flush to maintain access - essential after concentrated glucose
dosing.volume_resuscitation: 250-500ml bolus if hypotensive (rare in this scenario)

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Maintains IV access for medication administration. Critically important to flush after giving 40% glucose (concentrated solution irritates veins, can cause thrombophlebitis). Otherwise supportive role. Avoid large volume boluses unless patient hypotensive (unlikely in this scenario).
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Always flush IV after concentrated medications like glucose 40%. Good IV technique prevents complications. In this scenario, saline's main role is keeping IV patent and flushing after glucose.

critical_harm.name: propofol
critical_harm.primary_indication: Anesthesia induction, ICU sedation, refractory status epilepticus (ICU only)
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Profound respiratory depression, hypotension, requires intubation and ventilatory support. NOT for prehospital use.

if_given.patient_response: CRITICAL: Within 30 seconds of propofol administration, patient stops breathing. Her blood pressure drops to 85/50. She's deeply unconscious. You've caused respiratory arrest with propofol. Requires immediate intubation and ventilation. This medication has NO role in prehospital seizure management.
if_given.clinical_note: Propofol causes profound respiratory and cardiovascular depression. Used in ICU for refractory status epilepticus but requires mechanical ventilation and hemodynamic support. NEVER use prehospitally. This is a critical medication error.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Propofol is ICU medication for refractory status epilepticus ONLY, requires intubation and mechanical ventilation. Has NO role in prehospital care. Prehospital seizure treatment: (1) Glucose if hypoglycemic, (2) Benzodiazepines (diazepam 10-20mg max). If seizure continues after 20mg benzodiazepine, transport rapidly to hospital - don't use propofol. This is fundamental medication safety error.

critical_harm.name: succinylcholine
critical_harm.primary_indication: Rapid sequence intubation (RSI), muscle paralysis for intubation
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Causes PARALYSIS not seizure control. Patient still seizing internally (brain) but muscles paralyzed - cannot see it. Masks ongoing seizure. Causes respiratory arrest - requires immediate intubation.

vital_changes.seizure_actual: continuing in brain - you cannot see it
vital_changes.note: Paralyzed, apneic, seizure continues in brain

if_given.patient_response: CRITICAL: Patient suddenly stops moving. The seizure appears to stop - but it hasn't. You've PARALYZED her, not stopped the seizure. Her brain is still seizing but you cannot see it because muscles are paralyzed. She's not breathing - succinylcholine causes respiratory paralysis. You must intubate and ventilate immediately. This is a catastrophic error - you've masked ongoing brain injury and caused respiratory arrest.
if_given.clinical_note: Succinylcholine paralyzes muscles but does NOT stop seizures. Brain continues seizing while patient appears calm - this is DECEPTIVE and DANGEROUS. Ongoing seizure causes brain damage while provider falsely believes seizure stopped. Patient cannot breathe (paralyzed) - requires immediate intubation. This is gross misunderstanding of pharmacology.

critical_harm.teaching_point: NEVER give paralytics for seizures. Paralysis ≠ seizure control. Succinylcholine (and all paralytics) stop MUSCLE movement, not BRAIN seizure activity. Patient appears calm but brain continues seizing → ongoing brain damage. Plus you've caused respiratory arrest requiring immediate intubation. This is one of the most dangerous errors in seizure management. Treatment for seizures: benzodiazepines (stop brain activity), NOT paralytics (stop muscle activity).

critical_harm.name: naloxone
critical_harm.primary_indication: Opioid overdose, respiratory depression from opioids
critical_harm.why_dangerous_wrong_indication: Wrong diagnosis - patient has hypoglycemic seizure, not opioid overdose. Wasting critical time.

if_given.patient_response: Patient continues seizing. Naloxone has absolutely no effect because this is NOT opioid overdose. You've wasted 1-2 critical minutes administering wrong medication while patient's brain continues suffering. The boyfriend yells: 'She doesn't use drugs! She's diabetic! Why aren't you helping her?!'
if_given.clinical_note: Naloxone reverses opioids, not seizures or hypoglycemia. Diagnostic error - patient is SEIZING from HYPOGLYCEMIA (Type 1 diabetic, didn't eat, took insulin). Has nothing to do with opioids. Wasted time and missed actual problem. Check glucose, give glucose, stop seizure with benzodiazepine. Naloxone is completely irrelevant.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Seizures and opioid overdose look different. SEIZURE: active convulsions, rhythmic jerking, postictal confusion. OPIOID OD: depressed consciousness, pinpoint pupils, slow respirations, NO convulsions. This patient is actively seizing - not opioid pattern. History critical: Type 1 diabetic, known epilepsy, boyfriend says didn't eat. This screams HYPOGLYCEMIA → seizure. Check glucose, give glucose. Naloxone is wrong medication for wrong diagnosis.

moderate_harm.name: atropine
moderate_harm.primary_indication: Bradycardia, organophosphate poisoning, nerve agent exposure
moderate_harm.why_wrong: Patient is tachycardic (HR 135), not bradycardic. Atropine would worsen tachycardia. Seizures cause sympathetic surge → tachycardia. No indication.

if_given.patient_response: Patient's heart rate increases to 158/min. She's already tachycardic from seizure and sympathetic activation. Atropine makes it worse. No benefit to seizure control. You've caused unnecessary tachycardia.
if_given.clinical_note: Atropine increases heart rate - indicated for BRADYCARDIA. Patient already tachycardic (HR 135) - this is appropriate response to seizure/stress/hypoxia. Atropine worsens tachycardia with no therapeutic benefit. Wrong indication.

moderate_harm.teaching_point: Atropine for BRADYCARDIA (<50/min with poor perfusion). Patient is TACHYCARDIC (135/min) - this is normal response to seizure, hypoxia, and stress. Seizure increases sympathetic tone → tachycardia, hypertension. This is expected and doesn't need treatment. Atropine would make tachycardia worse. Focus on treating seizure (glucose + benzodiazepine if needed).

moderate_harm.name: amiodaron
moderate_harm.why_wrong: Patient in sinus tachycardia, not arrhythmia. Seizure doesn't require antiarrhythmics.

if_given.patient_response: No effect on seizure. Patient's sinus tachycardia continues (this is appropriate response to seizure). Amiodarone has no role here - patient doesn't have arrhythmia.
if_given.clinical_note: Amiodarone is for dangerous arrhythmias (VT, VF, AF with RVR). Patient has SINUS TACHYCARDIA - this is normal response to seizure/stress, not an arrhythmia requiring treatment. Wrong medication for wrong indication.

moderate_harm.teaching_point: Distinguish sinus tachycardia from arrhythmia. SINUS TACHYCARDIA: regular rhythm, rate 100-150, appropriate response to stress/illness. ARRHYTHMIA: irregular rhythm or very fast (>150), patient unstable. This patient: sinus tachycardia from seizure - normal and expected. Doesn't need antiarrhythmic. Treat the seizure and tachycardia will resolve.

moderate_harm.name: ketamine
moderate_harm.primary_indication: Pain management, procedural sedation, RSI adjunct, refractory status epilepticus (advanced)
moderate_harm.why_potentially_wrong: Can be used for refractory status epilepticus but NOT first-line. Check glucose and give benzodiazepines first.

vital_changes.seizure_activity: may stop but causes dissociation/emergence phenomena

if_given.patient_response: Seizure may stop but patient becomes dissociated, tachycardic, hypertensive. This is NOT standard prehospital treatment. Ketamine reserved for refractory seizures after benzodiazepines failed. Also - did you check glucose first?
if_given.clinical_note: Ketamine has role in refractory status epilepticus but NOT as first-line. Standard approach: (1) Check glucose, (2) Give glucose if low, (3) Benzodiazepine if seizure continues. Ketamine is advanced/experimental treatment. Using ketamine before glucose/benzodiazepines shows poor clinical reasoning.

moderate_harm.teaching_point: Ketamine emerging as option for refractory status epilepticus but this is ADVANCED treatment after standard therapies failed. Sequence: glucose (if low) → benzodiazepine 10mg → repeat benzo 10mg if needed → THEN consider ketamine if still seizing. Don't skip standard evidence-based treatments to use experimental advanced medication. Also causes sympathetic surge (tachycardia, hypertension) which may be undesirable.

worsens.name: metoprolol_tensiomin
worsens.why_wrong: Beta blockers can worsen hypoglycemia awareness (mask hypoglycemic symptoms) and impair recovery. Tachycardia is appropriate response - don't treat it.

if_given.patient_response: Heart rate decreases but patient continues seizing. Beta blocker masks tachycardia which is body's response to hypoglycemia. Makes it harder for body to recover from low glucose. No benefit to seizure, potential harm to glucose regulation.
if_given.clinical_note: Beta blockers mask symptoms of hypoglycemia (tachycardia, tremor, sweating) making it harder to recognize and recover from. In diabetics, beta blockers are problematic. Tachycardia during seizure is APPROPRIATE response - don't suppress it. Worsens situation.

worsens.teaching_point: Beta blockers problematic in diabetics because they mask hypoglycemic symptoms. Body responds to low glucose with sympathetic surge (tachycardia, sweating, tremor) - this is PROTECTIVE, helps mobilize glucose. Beta blockers block these responses → harder to recognize and recover from hypoglycemia. Never give beta blockers during hypoglycemic crisis. Tachycardia during seizure is expected and appropriate - don't treat it.

worsens.name: insulin
worsens.why_dangerous: Patient is HYPO-glycemic (glucose 1.8). Giving insulin would be catastrophic - would drop glucose further, worsen seizure, potentially fatal.

if_given.patient_response: CRITICAL: You've made a catastrophic error. Patient is HYPO-glycemic (low glucose 1.8), not HYPER-glycemic. Giving insulin drops glucose further to 0.8 - critically dangerously low. Seizure intensifies. Patient at risk of death from severe hypoglycemia. You've done the OPPOSITE of what patient needs. This is potentially fatal error.
if_given.clinical_note: Giving insulin to hypoglycemic patient is gross error that can cause death. Patient NEEDS glucose, not more insulin. This is fundamental misunderstanding of pathophysiology. Possibly student saw 'diabetic' and reflexively gave insulin without thinking or checking glucose level.

worsens.teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose before giving insulin. Type 1 diabetics can be either HYPO-glycemic (too much insulin, not enough food) or HYPER-glycemic (not enough insulin, too much food). This patient: took insulin, didn't eat → HYPOglycemia → seizure. Needs GLUCOSE, not more insulin. Giving insulin would be fatal. This error demonstrates failure to assess (didn't check glucose) and failure to think (assumed diabetic = needs insulin without considering hypoglycemia).

neutral.name: aspirin
neutral.why_unnecessary: Not indicated for seizures or hypoglycemia. Wastes time.

if_given.patient_response: Patient continues seizing. Aspirin has no effect on seizures. You've wasted time giving irrelevant medication.

neutral.teaching_point: Aspirin for cardiovascular disease (ACS, stroke prevention). This is NEUROLOGICAL emergency (seizure) from METABOLIC cause (hypoglycemia). Stay focused on actual problem.

neutral.name: nitroglycerine
neutral.why_unnecessary: Not indicated for seizures. May cause hypotension.

if_given.patient_response: Patient continues seizing. Blood pressure drops slightly. No benefit. Potentially harmful if causes significant hypotension.

neutral.teaching_point: Nitrates for cardiac ischemia. This is seizure from hypoglycemia. Unrelated. Stay focused.

neutral.name: morphine
neutral.why_unnecessary_and_harmful: Patient unconscious/seizing - cannot assess pain. Morphine causes respiratory depression (adds to risk from benzodiazepine). No indication.

if_given.patient_response: Patient continues seizing. Respiratory rate decreases slightly from morphine's depressant effect. No benefit, potential harm.
if_given.clinical_note: Morphine has no role in seizure management. Causes respiratory depression which is problematic in already-hypoxic seizing patient. If benzodiazepine also given, risk of respiratory failure increases (two respiratory depressants). Wasted drug and added risk.

neutral.teaching_point: Opioids have no role in seizure management. Patient unconscious - cannot assess pain. Morphine causes respiratory depression, adding to risk from benzodiazepines. Seizures are NOT painful to patient (unconscious during event). Focus on stopping seizure (glucose + benzodiazepine), not giving unnecessary drugs that add risk.

neutral.name: furosemide
neutral.why_wrong: Wrong pathology - this is seizure, not fluid overload. Diagnostic confusion.

if_given.patient_response: No effect. Patient continues seizing. Furosemide treats fluid overload, not seizures.

neutral.teaching_point: Furosemide for PULMONARY EDEMA (fluid in lungs - crackles, pink frothy sputum). Patient has SEIZURE (convulsions). Completely different pathologies. This suggests fundamental diagnostic confusion.

neutral.name: adrenaline_epinephrine
neutral.why_wrong: Not indicated for seizures. May worsen tachycardia and hypertension. Could theoretically raise glucose slightly but glucose IV is far superior.

vital_changes.note: Severe tachycardia and hypertension, minimal glucose effect

if_given.patient_response: Patient's heart rate jumps to 162, blood pressure to 178/98. Seizure continues. Epinephrine causes massive sympathetic surge without stopping seizure. Glucose rises slightly (2.1) from epinephrine's glycogenolytic effect but not enough to stop seizure. Wrong medication - use glucose IV instead.
if_given.clinical_note: Epinephrine has minor effect on blood glucose (stimulates glycogenolysis) but this is NOT the way to treat hypoglycemia. Causes dangerous tachycardia and hypertension without adequately raising glucose. Give glucose IV directly instead. Shows poor pharmacologic reasoning.

neutral.teaching_point: Epinephrine for ANAPHYLAXIS and CARDIAC ARREST. Not for seizures or hypoglycemia. While epinephrine does raise blood glucose slightly (via glycogenolysis), this is inadequate for severe hypoglycemia and causes dangerous cardiovascular effects (tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmia risk). Treat hypoglycemia with GLUCOSE IV - direct, effective, safe. Don't use epinephrine as indirect glucose-raising agent.

appropriate_advanced.name: phenytoin
appropriate_advanced.why_advanced: Second-line agent for status epilepticus after benzodiazepines. Requires slow IV infusion (>30 min). More appropriate for hospital than prehospital but shows advanced knowledge.
appropriate_advanced.requires: IV access, cardiac monitoring, slow infusion 15-20mg/kg over 30+ minutes, given AFTER benzodiazepines

if_given.patient_response: Phenytoin requires 20-30 minute infusion for full effect. Seizure gradually controlled. This is appropriate second-line agent but slow onset makes it less ideal prehospitally. Better choice: benzodiazepines (faster). If you gave phenytoin AFTER benzodiazepines and glucose, this shows advanced knowledge. If you gave phenytoin FIRST, this shows poor prioritization.
if_given.clinical_note: Phenytoin is evidence-based for status epilepticus but second-line (after benzodiazepines). Requires prolonged infusion limiting prehospital utility. Shows good pharmacologic knowledge if used appropriately (after first-line treatments) but poor judgment if used instead of faster-acting agents.

appropriate_advanced.teaching_point: Phenytoin is appropriate second-line anticonvulsant for status epilepticus refractory to benzodiazepines. However: (1) Slow onset (20-30 min infusion), (2) Cannot give rapidly (causes arrhythmias, hypotension), (3) Better suited for hospital than prehospital. Prehospital: give glucose (if hypoglycemic) + benzodiazepine (fast onset), then transport. Phenytoin shows good knowledge but represents 'overthinking' prehospital care - stick to basics that work quickly.

appropriate_advanced.name: glucagon
appropriate_advanced.why_acceptable_alternative: Raises blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis. Use when IV access difficult.
appropriate_advanced.requires: 1mg IM injection, patient must have glycogen stores (doesn't work if chronically malnourished/alcoholic)

vital_changes.note: Slower than IV glucose but effective

if_given.patient_response: After 5-10 minutes, patient's blood glucose rises to 4.8. Seizure gradually stops. Patient likely vomits as she wakes up (common side effect of glucagon). This is acceptable alternative to IV glucose if IV access difficult, but slower and less reliable. If you had IV access, glucose IV is better. If IV access was difficult, glucagon shows good clinical judgment.
if_given.clinical_note: Glucagon 1mg IM is acceptable alternative to IV glucose when IV access unavailable or difficult. Onset slower (5-10 min vs 1-2 min for IV glucose) and causes nausea/vomiting as side effect. Less reliable in chronic alcoholics or malnourished patients (need glycogen stores). Shows good knowledge of alternatives but IV glucose remains gold standard.

appropriate_advanced.teaching_point: Glucagon excellent backup when IV access unavailable. Give 1mg IM. Raises glucose by mobilizing glycogen from liver. Slower than IV glucose (5-10 min vs 1-2 min) and causes nausea/vomiting. Doesn't work in patients without glycogen stores (chronic alcoholics, severely malnourished). Sequence: (1) Try IV access, (2) If successful, give glucose IV, (3) If IV difficult/impossible, give glucagon IM, (4) Keep trying for IV access. Both achieve same goal (raise glucose) via different routes.

glucose_40_percent.patient_says: After 3-5 min: confused groaning. After 10 min: 'What happened? Where am I? Did I have a seizure?'
glucose_40_percent.clinical_effect: Treats underlying cause - seizure stops as brain glucose normalized

diazepam.patient_says: Unconscious during. After 5-10 min: confused groaning, very drowsy
diazepam.clinical_effect: Suppresses seizure but doesn't treat cause. More sedation than glucose alone.

oxygen.clinical_effect: Improves oxygenation during inadequate ventilation from seizure

midazolam.clinical_effect: Equivalent to diazepam for seizure control

3_minutes.patient_status: Seizure continuing, cyanosis worsening, boyfriend crying 'Please help her!'
3_minutes.clinical_note: Seizure ongoing, now 9-10 minutes total duration. Brain damage risk increasing. Hypoxia worsening. CRITICAL to intervene NOW - check glucose, give glucose if low, prepare benzodiazepine.

5_minutes.patient_status: Seizure persisting, severe hypoxia, secretions accumulating
5_minutes.clinical_note: Status epilepticus continues. Now 11-12 minutes total. CRITICAL intervention point. If glucose not checked, hypoglycemia persists as underlying cause. If benzodiazepine not given, seizure causes progressive brain damage. Must act immediately.

10_minutes.patient_status: Approaching respiratory failure. Seizure may be slowing from exhaustion but patient becoming more cyanotic, respirations failing.
10_minutes.clinical_note: Respiratory failure imminent. Even if seizure slows, metabolic exhaustion and hypoxic brain injury severe. Requires immediate intervention - BVM ventilation, glucose, benzodiazepine. Poor prognosis if treatment continues to be delayed. Risk of cardiac arrest from hypoxia.

challenge_points.challenge: Check Glucose BEFORE Benzodiazepine - Treating Cause vs Suppressing Symptoms
challenge_points.scenario_context: Patient is Type 1 diabetic with hypoglycemia (1.8 mmol/L) causing seizure. Student must recognize need to check glucose immediately, not reflexively give benzodiazepine.

trigger.condition: student about to give diazepam or has given diazepam without checking glucose first

factors_to_consider: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients, especially known diabetics
Hypoglycemia is REVERSIBLE cause - treating it stops seizure faster and safer than benzodiazepine
Sequence: (1) Protect airway/oxygen, (2) Check glucose immediately, (3) Give glucose if <3.5, (4) Give benzodiazepine if seizure continues after glucose OR if glucose normal
Boyfriend's history: 'She didn't eat yesterday, felt sick, not sure if she took insulin'
Clinical clues: Type 1 diabetic + didn't eat + took insulin = HYPOGLYCEMIA
Treating cause is better than suppressing symptoms

scoring.optimal: Checked glucose within first 60 seconds of patient contact (while partner prepares O2/suction). Immediately recognized hypoglycemia as likely cause given history (diabetic, didn't eat, took insulin). Verbalized reasoning: 'Type 1 diabetic who didn't eat - I need to check glucose first before assuming this is just her epilepsy.' Gave glucose 40% 50ml IV within 2 minutes of arrival. Held benzodiazepine initially to see if glucose alone stops seizure. Demonstrated critical thinking: treating CAUSE (hypoglycemia) not just SYMPTOM (seizure). Prepared benzodiazepine as backup if seizure continues after glucose.
scoring.acceptable: Checked glucose within first 2-3 minutes. Recognized hypoglycemia and gave glucose appropriately. May have given benzodiazepine simultaneously or shortly after glucose rather than waiting to see glucose effect first. Got to correct treatment (glucose) reasonably quickly even if sequence not perfect. Demonstrated awareness that hypoglycemia causes seizures and needs correction.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave benzodiazepine first (5-10mg) without checking glucose initially, THEN checked glucose later when seizure didn't stop or when prompted. Eventually gave glucose but missed opportunity for faster, safer treatment. OR checked glucose but gave benzodiazepine before glucose (wrong sequence). Achieved correct treatments eventually but poor prioritization. Showed 'reflexive' thinking (see seizure → give diazepam) rather than 'investigative' thinking (why is this happening?)
scoring.dangerous: Never checked glucose at all, OR gave benzodiazepine repeatedly without ever considering hypoglycemia as cause. Treated seizure as 'epilepsy flare' without investigating underlying cause. Seizure may stop eventually from benzodiazepine but patient remains hypoglycemic → prolonged altered mental status, risk of re-seizure, potential harm from excessive benzodiazepine dosing (respiratory depression). Missed reversible cause that could have been corrected in 2 minutes. Demonstrates failure to think critically about 'why' patient seizing.

challenge_points.teaching_goal: Critical thinking about seizure etiology. Always ask 'WHY is this patient seizing?' Don't just reflexively treat symptoms. The mnemonic 'VITAMINS' helps: Vascular, Infection, Trauma, Aura (epilepsy), Metabolic (HYPOGLYCEMIA, hyponatremia), Iatrogenic, Neoplasm, Syncope. Check for reversible causes FIRST.
challenge_points.aar_teaching_point: This is THE critical decision point in this scenario. Hypoglycemia causes seizures and is immediately reversible with glucose - faster and safer than benzodiazepines. The key clues were: (1) Type 1 diabetic, (2) Didn't eat yesterday/today, (3) May have taken insulin despite not eating. This is classic hypoglycemia setup. ALWAYS check glucose in EVERY seizure patient - takes 30 seconds and could save a life. Correct sequence: (1) Scene safety, (2) Position patient (recovery position), (3) Oxygen, (4) Check glucose IMMEDIATELY, (5) Give glucose if <3.5, (6) Give benzodiazepine if seizure continues after glucose or if glucose normal. Treating the CAUSE is better than suppressing the SYMPTOM.

challenge_points.challenge: Benzodiazepine Dose Titration - Balance Seizure Control vs Respiratory Depression
challenge_points.scenario_context: Student must decide appropriate diazepam dose and recognize when second dose needed, while avoiding excessive dosing causing respiratory depression.

trigger.condition: student preparing to give or has given diazepam

factors_to_consider: Standard adult dose: 10mg IV diazepam for status epilepticus
May repeat 10mg after 5-10 minutes if seizure continues (max 20mg prehospital)
Giving 5mg usually inadequate for status epilepticus (under-dosing)
Giving 20mg all at once causes respiratory depression (over-dosing)
Must balance: stopping seizure vs risk of respiratory depression
Monitor RR closely - if RR <10 or SpO2 dropping despite oxygen, respiratory depression developing
Have BVM ready - respiratory depression is major risk

scoring.optimal: Verbalized reasoning: 'I'll give 10mg IV diazepam slowly over 2-3 minutes - that's the standard dose for status epilepticus. Then I'll wait 5 minutes to assess effect. If seizure continues, I can give a second 10mg dose for total of 20mg maximum. I need to monitor her respiratory rate closely because benzodiazepines can cause respiratory depression.' Gave 10mg appropriately, waited 5 minutes to assess, prepared to give second dose if needed. Had BVM ready. Monitored RR and SpO2 continuously. Demonstrated understanding of dose titration principles and respiratory depression risk.
scoring.acceptable: Gave 10mg diazepam IV appropriately. May not have explicitly verbalized titration plan but acted correctly when assessing effect and considering second dose if needed. Monitored vital signs appropriately. Demonstrated safe practice even if not perfectly articulated.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave inadequate dose (5mg) and seizure continues, OR gave appropriate first dose but didn't recognize treatment failure when seizure continued/recurred and didn't consider second dose. OR gave correct total dose (10-20mg) but too rapidly without waiting to assess first dose effect. OR didn't monitor respiratory rate closely after giving benzodiazepine. Eventually achieved seizure control but suboptimal technique.
scoring.dangerous: Gave excessive dose (20mg all at once or >20mg total) causing severe respiratory depression (RR <10, SpO2 <85 despite oxygen). Patient now has TWO problems: seizure AND respiratory failure from over-sedation. Requires BVM ventilation. Demonstrates failure to understand dose-response relationship and major risk of benzodiazepines. OR gave multiple doses without monitoring effect, stacking doses dangerously.

challenge_points.teaching_goal: Understanding benzodiazepine titration for status epilepticus. Balance therapeutic goal (stop seizure) with major side effect (respiratory depression). The skill is finding the 'sweet spot' - enough drug to stop seizure, not so much that patient stops breathing.
challenge_points.aar_teaching_point: Status epilepticus treatment requires careful dose titration. TOO LITTLE benzodiazepine = seizure continues = ongoing brain damage. TOO MUCH = respiratory depression = hypoxia = brain damage. The correct approach: (1) Start with 10mg IV diazepam, (2) Give slowly (5mg/min), (3) Wait 5-10 minutes to assess effect, (4) Give second 10mg if seizure continues, (5) Maximum 20mg prehospital. Monitor RR and SpO2 continuously - if RR dropping or SpO2 not improving despite oxygen, respiratory depression developing. Have BVM ready. Never give all 20mg at once - causes dangerous respiratory depression. This is why we say 'titrate to effect' - start with standard dose, reassess, add more only if needed. Critical skill in emergency medicine: balancing efficacy vs safety.

challenge_points.challenge: Airway Management During Active Seizure - What NOT To Do
challenge_points.scenario_context: Patient actively seizing with clenched jaw. Student must manage airway safely WITHOUT dangerous interventions like forcing oral airway into clenched mouth.

trigger.condition: student attempting to insert oral airway during active seizure with clenched jaw

factors_to_consider: During active tonic-clonic seizure, jaw is clenched tight - physically impossible to insert oral airway safely
Attempting to force OPA breaks teeth, injures jaw, damages airway device

Correct approach during seizure: (1) Position on side (recovery position), (2) Clear furniture/hazards, (3) Suction visible secretions, (4) Apply oxygen, (5) Have BVM ready, (6) Do NOT force anything into mouth
AFTER seizure stops, THEN insert OPA if needed
Never restrain seizing patient - increases injury risk

scoring.optimal: Recognized jaw clenched during active seizure and verbalized: 'I cannot insert oral airway while she's actively seizing - the jaw is clenched. That would risk breaking teeth or injuring her.' Instead: positioned patient on side (recovery position), cleared furniture away for safety, suctioned secretions from mouth that were accessible without forcing anything, applied high-flow oxygen (NRB or held near face), had BVM ready in case ventilation needed. Waited until seizure stopped, THEN reassessed airway and inserted OPA if needed. Protected patient from harm during seizure without dangerous interventions.
scoring.acceptable: Initially considered inserting OPA but quickly recognized jaw clenched and changed approach. May have touched jaw to assess but didn't force anything. Pivoted to appropriate positioning (recovery position), suctioning what's accessible, and oxygen. Demonstrated good judgment even if initial instinct wasn't perfect.
scoring.suboptimal: Attempted to insert OPA during active seizure but didn't force it aggressively. May have wasted 30-60 seconds trying before recognizing futility. Eventually moved to appropriate management (positioning, oxygen) but delayed by incorrect initial approach. OR used excessive force with suction catheter trying to reach posterior pharynx during seizure (should only suction what's easily accessible).
scoring.dangerous: Forcefully attempted to insert oral airway or bite stick during active seizure with clenched jaw. Broke patient's teeth, injured oral mucosa, or damaged jaw. Caused harm trying to help. OR attempted to restrain patient during seizure (increases injury risk from fighting against restraints). OR attempted advanced airway (intubation, LMA) during active seizure - extremely dangerous and inappropriate. Demonstrates fundamental misunderstanding of seizure airway management.

challenge_points.teaching_goal: Safe airway management during seizures. Understanding WHAT you CAN do vs WHAT you CANNOT do during active convulsions. Protecting patient from iatrogenic harm.
challenge_points.aar_teaching_point: Common dangerous mistake: trying to force oral airway into seizing patient's mouth. NEVER do this. During active tonic-clonic seizure, masseter muscles (jaw muscles) are contracted with tremendous force - jaw is clenched tight. Attempting to force OPA will: (1) Break patient's teeth, (2) Injure jaw or TMJ, (3) Break the airway device, (4) Lacerate your fingers if patient bites down. You CANNOT insert OPA during active seizure with clenched jaw - it's physically impossible and dangerous to try. Correct approach: (1) Position patient on side (recovery position) - protects airway, allows secretions to drain, (2) Remove hazards from area, (3) Suction visible secretions in mouth (only what's accessible - don't force deep suctioning), (4) Apply high-flow oxygen (NRB at 15L/min or hold near face), (5) Have BVM ready if ventilation needed, (6) WAIT for seizure to stop. AFTER seizure terminates, THEN reassess airway. If patient unconscious with no gag reflex, insert OPA at that time. If patient has gag reflex returning, use nasal airway or position only. Also: NEVER restrain seizing patient - let the seizure happen while protecting from injury. Restraints increase risk of fractures and injuries from fighting against restraints. Your job during active seizure: protect airway by positioning, protect patient from environmental hazards, support oxygenation, prepare definitive treatment (glucose/benzodiazepine). Do NOT attempt heroic airway interventions during active convulsions.

challenge_points.challenge: Post-Ictal Confusion is Normal - Don't Over-Treat
challenge_points.scenario_context: After seizure stops, patient remains confused (GCS 10-12), disoriented. Student must recognize this is EXPECTED postictal state, not a complication requiring more treatment.

trigger.condition: patient stopped seizing but remains confused/unresponsive initially

factors_to_consider: Postictal state is NORMAL neurological recovery after seizure
GCS gradually improves: 6-7 (immediately post-seizure) → 10-12 (10 min later) → 14-15 (20-30 min)
Patient will be confused, drowsy, may not remember event
This is NORMAL and expected - brain needs time to 'reboot' after seizure
Key differentiator: if properly treated (glucose corrected, seizure stopped), GCS GRADUALLY IMPROVES
If GCS stays 3 or worsens, that's abnormal - suggests ongoing problem

scoring.optimal: After seizure stopped, student reassured boyfriend: 'The seizure has stopped - that's good. She's going to be confused and sleepy for 10-30 minutes while her brain recovers. This is completely normal after a seizure. Watch - her consciousness will gradually improve over the next 10-20 minutes.' Monitored GCS serially (q5 min) and documented gradual improvement (GCS 7 → 10 → 12 → 14). Recognized this as normal postictal state. Didn't administer additional sedation or unnecessary medications. Focused on supportive care (maintain airway, oxygen, monitor vitals) and recheck glucose. Educated patient and boyfriend about postictal period.
scoring.acceptable: Recognized patient is in postictal state even if didn't explicitly name it. Monitored consciousness appropriately and noted gradual improvement. Provided supportive care. May not have perfectly articulated to boyfriend that this is normal, but acted appropriately by monitoring and not over-treating.
scoring.suboptimal: Showed concern about continued decreased consciousness but eventually recognized gradual improvement with monitoring. May have considered additional interventions unnecessarily (more benzodiazepine, advanced airway) before recognizing postictal state. Eventually reached correct conclusion but with some uncertainty or alarm initially.
scoring.dangerous: Panicked when patient didn't immediately wake up after seizure stopped. Gave additional benzodiazepine thinking patient needed more sedation control (wrong - will prolong decreased consciousness). OR attempted aggressive stimulation or painful stimuli inappropriately. OR called for helicopter evacuation thinking patient in critical condition when actually just in normal postictal state. Failed to recognize normal post-seizure recovery pattern.

challenge_points.teaching_goal: Understanding postictal state as normal phenomenon. Distinguishing normal post-seizure recovery from pathological ongoing decreased consciousness. Knowing when to support vs when to escalate.
challenge_points.aar_teaching_point: The postictal state is NORMAL neurological recovery period after seizure - it is NOT a complication or treatment failure. After any seizure (generalized tonic-clonic), the brain needs 10-30 minutes (sometimes longer) to recover. During this time, patient will be: (1) Confused and disoriented ('Where am I? What happened?'), (2) Drowsy and difficult to wake fully, (3) May have amnesia for the event, (4) May have headache or muscle soreness, (5) Wants to sleep. This is the brain 'rebooting' after massive neuronal discharge. It's expected and normal. The KEY DIFFERENTIATOR between normal postictal state and ongoing problem: TREND. In normal postictal state, GCS GRADUALLY IMPROVES over 10-30 minutes (6-7 → 10-12 → 14-15). Patient becoming progressively more awake and oriented. If you treated underlying cause (gave glucose for hypoglycemia, gave benzodiazepine if needed), patient will wake up - just give it time. ABNORMAL patterns that require concern: (1) GCS remains 3 (deeply unconscious) 10+ minutes after seizure stopped - suggests ongoing problem, (2) GCS improving then suddenly drops again - suggests second seizure or complication, (3) Focal neurological signs appearing (weakness one side, unequal pupils) - suggests structural problem. But normal postictal confusion/drowsiness with GRADUAL improvement = no additional treatment needed, just supportive care and monitoring. Your job: (1) Maintain airway (recovery position), (2) Give oxygen if SpO2 <94%, (3) Monitor vitals and GCS q5min, (4) Recheck glucose, (5) Reassure patient and family, (6) Transport for evaluation. DO NOT: give more sedation (will prolong unconsciousness), attempt aggressive stimulation (let patient rest), panic about normal recovery process. It's called 'post-ICTAL state' (ictal = during seizure, post-ictal = after seizure). This is one of the classic patterns in neurology - learn to recognize it.

cognitive_coach_questions.question: You're reaching for diazepam - that's our primary seizure medication. But before we give it, I want you to think about something: what's this patient's medical history that might give us a clue about WHY she's seizing? And is there a quick test we should do first that might change our treatment approach?
cognitive_coach_questions.teaching_goal: Prompt critical thinking about hypoglycemia as reversible cause before reflexively giving benzodiazepine
acceptable_responses: Boyfriend said she didn't eat - might be low glucose

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Exactly right. She's a Type 1 diabetic who didn't eat but may have taken insulin - classic setup for hypoglycemia. And hypoglycemia CAUSES seizures. Let's check her glucose right now - takes 30 seconds. If it's low, we can treat the CAUSE with glucose rather than just suppressing the symptom with diazepam. Treating the cause is faster and safer. Check the glucose first, THEN decide about diazepam based on what we find.
resolution.if_protocol_only: You're thinking about protocols - good. But I want you to think deeper: WHY is she seizing? Look at her medical history... Type 1 diabetic, didn't eat yesterday, boyfriend not sure if she took insulin. What does that suggest? What reversible cause could we check in 30 seconds that would completely change our treatment?
resolution.if_struggling: Let me give you the key information: Type 1 diabetic + didn't eat + may have taken insulin = very high risk for HYPOGLYCEMIA. And hypoglycemia CAUSES seizures. Before giving diazepam (which suppresses seizures but doesn't fix the cause), let's check her glucose. If it's low, we treat with glucose and the seizure stops because we fixed the problem. Make sense? Check glucose first - takes 30 seconds, could save us from missing the reversible cause.

cognitive_coach_questions.question: I see you're trying to insert an oral airway. Before you do that, take a look at the patient's jaw - is it clenched or relaxed right now? And what might happen if we try to force an airway into a clenched jaw during an active seizure?
cognitive_coach_questions.teaching_goal: Recognize danger of forcing oral airway during active seizure with clenched jaw
acceptable_responses: Jaw is clenched - can't insert airway
Can't force it during active seizure
Need to wait until seizure stops

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Exactly right. The jaw is clenched tight during this tonic-clonic seizure - it's physically impossible to insert an OPA safely right now. If we try to force it, we'll break teeth, injure the jaw, or damage the device. Instead, let's position her on her side (recovery position), suction the secretions we can access without forcing anything, and apply high-flow oxygen. We'll have a BVM ready if she needs ventilation assistance. After the seizure stops, we can reassess the airway and insert an OPA if needed. Trying to force an airway during active seizure is one of the classic dangerous mistakes - we need to avoid it.
resolution.if_unsure: Take a closer look at her jaw and mouth. During a tonic-clonic seizure, the masseter muscles contract with tremendous force - the jaw is clenched TIGHT. We physically cannot open it safely. What do you think would happen if we tried to force an oral airway against that much resistance?
resolution.if_struggling: Here's the key principle: during an active seizure with a clenched jaw, we CANNOT safely insert an oral airway. Attempting to force it causes broken teeth, jaw injuries, or damages the device. Instead, our airway management during active seizure focuses on: (1) positioning (recovery position on side), (2) suctioning accessible secretions, (3) high-flow oxygen, (4) having BVM ready if needed. We do NOT force anything into the mouth. After the seizure stops and the jaw relaxes, THEN we can insert an OPA if the patient needs it. This is a critical safety principle - forcing airways during seizures causes preventable injuries.

cognitive_coach_questions.question: You gave 5mg of diazepam. That's a dose of diazepam, but let me ask: what's the standard dose for status epilepticus in adults? And if this seizure has been going on for 6-7 minutes already, is 5mg likely to be enough?
cognitive_coach_questions.teaching_goal: Recognize that 5mg diazepam is typically inadequate for status epilepticus - standard dose is 10mg
acceptable_responses: 5mg probably not enough for status epilepticus

resolution.if_good_reasoning: You're right - standard dose for status epilepticus is 10mg IV. Five milligrams might be sufficient for a brief seizure or for elderly patients, but for status epilepticus (seizure >5 minutes) in a 34-year-old, we typically need 10mg. Let's watch her response over the next few minutes. If the seizure continues, we should give another 5mg to bring her to the 10mg dose. We can give up to 20mg total (two 10mg doses) for status epilepticus if needed. The goal is to stop the seizure while monitoring for respiratory depression.
resolution.if_unsure: Think about it: she's been seizing for 6-7 minutes already - this is status epilepticus, a true neurological emergency. The brain is being damaged the longer this continues. Five milligrams is on the lighter side - more appropriate for brief seizures or very elderly patients. Standard adult dose for status epilepticus is 10mg. What should we do if the seizure doesn't stop with the 5mg you gave?
resolution.if_struggling: Let me clarify the dosing: For status epilepticus (seizure >5 minutes), the standard adult dose is 10mg IV diazepam. You can repeat 10mg after 5-10 minutes if needed, for a maximum of 20mg total prehospitally. Five milligrams is typically inadequate for true status epilepticus - it's a dose we might use for brief seizures or very elderly patients. Since you gave 5mg, let's monitor closely for the next 2-3 minutes. If the seizure continues, give another 5mg to reach the 10mg dose. The goal is adequate seizure control while avoiding respiratory depression from excessive dosing.

cognitive_coach_questions.question: The seizure has stopped but the patient is still very drowsy and confused - GCS around 10. The boyfriend is worried: 'Why isn't she waking up? Is something wrong?' What do you tell him? Is this level of consciousness normal after a seizure, or is it concerning?
cognitive_coach_questions.teaching_goal: Recognize postictal state as normal, provide appropriate education and reassurance
acceptable_responses: This is normal after a seizure
Postictal state - she needs time to recover

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Perfect - you understand the postictal state. You'd tell the boyfriend: 'This is completely normal after a seizure. Her brain needs time to recover - usually 10-30 minutes. She'll be confused and sleepy right now, but watch: her consciousness will gradually improve. She'll become more awake and oriented over the next 10-20 minutes.' Then you'd monitor her GCS every 5 minutes and document the gradual improvement (10 → 12 → 14 → 15). The key is that she's IMPROVING, even if slowly. This is expected recovery, not a complication. We provide supportive care (maintain airway, oxygen, monitor) and transport for evaluation, but we don't panic about normal postictal confusion.
resolution.if_unsure: Think about what happens to the brain during a seizure - it's essentially a massive electrical storm with all neurons firing chaotically. After that kind of event, does it make sense that the brain would instantly return to normal? Or would it need some recovery time?
resolution.if_struggling: This is called the 'postictal state' - the period after (post) a seizure (ictal). It's completely normal. The brain needs 10-30 minutes to 'reboot' after the massive neuronal discharge of a seizure. During this time, patients are drowsy, confused, may not remember what happened. The critical thing to assess is: is consciousness GRADUALLY IMPROVING? If yes (GCS going from 6 → 10 → 12 → 15 over 20 minutes), that's normal postictal recovery. If no (GCS stays 3 or worsens), that's concerning and suggests ongoing problem. In this case, if we treated her hypoglycemia with glucose and stopped the seizure, she'll gradually wake up over the next 10-20 minutes. This is expected. We monitor, provide supportive care, and transport - but we don't give more sedation or panic. It's normal recovery.

airway.initial: Compromised during active seizure - jaw clenched, gurgling sounds from secretions, patient cannot protect airway. Copious saliva pooling in mouth. Risk of aspiration.
airway.improving: Airway patent after seizure stops. Patient in recovery position, breathing spontaneously. May have residual secretions - suction as needed.
airway.deteriorating: Airway compromised again with recurrent seizure. Increased secretions, inadequate protective reflexes.
airway.critical: Airway at high risk - patient not breathing adequately, deeply unconscious. Requires aggressive airway management, likely BVM.

breathing.initial: Inadequate ventilation during seizure - irregular rate 18-24/min, poor tidal volume due to muscle contractions. SpO2 88% (hypoxic). Requires high-flow oxygen immediately.
breathing.improving: Breathing improving post-seizure. RR 20, more regular pattern. SpO2 94% on oxygen. Continue oxygen support.
breathing.deteriorating: Breathing deteriorating with recurrent seizure or from excessive benzodiazepine. SpO2 dropping, inadequate respiratory effort.
breathing.critical: Respiratory failure - RR 8 or less, shallow breaths, SpO2 75%. Requires immediate BVM ventilation. May need advanced airway.

circulation.initial: Tachycardia HR 135 (appropriate response to seizure/stress/hypoxia), BP elevated 155/92 (sympathetic surge). Perfusion adequate despite hypoxia. Skin pale, diaphoretic.
circulation.improving: HR decreasing to 118, BP normalizing 145/88. Perfusion good, color improving. Warm extremities.
circulation.deteriorating: HR remains elevated 142, BP variable. Perfusion may be compromised if second seizure or cardiovascular instability.
circulation.critical: HR very elevated 148 or cardiovascular instability developing. Perfusion may be compromised if prolonged hypoxia.

disability.initial: GCS 3 during active seizure (E1 V1 M1) - eyes closed/rolling back, no verbal response, abnormal motor activity (convulsing). Pupils difficult to assess during active convulsions.
disability.improving: GCS 6-7 immediately post-ictal (E2 V1 M3), gradually improving to GCS 10-12 (E3 V3 M4), then to 14-15 over 10-20 minutes. Pupils reactive. No focal deficits. This is normal postictal recovery.
disability.deteriorating: GCS remains 3 with recurrent seizure or inadequate treatment. Ongoing neurological compromise.
disability.critical: GCS 3, unresponsive, may or may not be actively seizing. Profound neurological depression from prolonged seizure or excessive sedation or respiratory failure.

exposure.initial: Incontinent of urine (common in tonic-clonic seizures). Check for tongue bite (common). No external trauma visible. Temperature 37.2°C (normal - rules out febrile seizure in adult). Patient wearing pajamas, in bedroom setting.
exposure.improving: No injuries found on examination. Urine-soaked clothing should be changed for dignity. No fever. No signs of trauma from seizure.
exposure.deteriorating: No new findings on exposure exam.
exposure.critical: No trauma. Focus on life-threatening ABCs.

critical_actions_checklist.action: Prepare for rapid transport with pre-hospital notification
critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Called receiving hospital, provided report: '34F with status epilepticus and hypoglycemia, Type 1 diabetic, seizure terminated with glucose and/or benzodiazepine, vitals stable, ETA X minutes'

common_errors.error: Gave benzodiazepine without checking blood glucose first
common_errors.teaching_point: CRITICAL ERROR: Always check glucose before treating seizures, especially in diabetics. Hypoglycemia causes seizures and is immediately reversible with glucose - faster and safer than benzodiazepines. Giving diazepam without checking glucose misses the treatable cause. The seizure may stop from benzodiazepine but patient remains hypoglycemic → prolonged confusion or recurrent seizures. ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients - takes 30 seconds and could save a life. Correct sequence: (1) Position/airway, (2) Oxygen, (3) Check glucose, (4) Give glucose if <3.5, (5) Give benzodiazepine if seizure continues or if glucose normal. In this scenario, glucose IS the treatment.

common_errors.error: Tried to force oral airway into clenched mouth during active seizure
common_errors.teaching_point: DANGEROUS ERROR: NEVER force anything into a seizing patient's mouth. During tonic-clonic seizure, jaw is clenched with tremendous force - you physically cannot insert OPA safely. Attempting to force it causes: broken teeth, jaw injury, damaged equipment, possibly lacerated fingers. Correct approach during active seizure: (1) Position on side (recovery position), (2) Suction accessible secretions only, (3) Apply oxygen, (4) Have BVM ready. Insert OPA AFTER seizure stops if patient needs it. This is one of the classic dangerous mistakes in seizure management - avoid it.

common_errors.error: Gave inadequate diazepam dose (5mg) or excessive dose (>20mg)
common_errors.teaching_point: Dosing error: Standard adult dose for status epilepticus is 10mg IV diazepam. Can repeat 10mg after 5-10 minutes if seizure continues (max 20mg prehospital). Giving 5mg is usually inadequate for true status epilepticus - seizure continues, brain continues being damaged. Giving >20mg or giving 20mg all at once causes dangerous respiratory depression - patient stops breathing, requires BVM. The skill is finding balance: enough to stop seizure, not so much that patient stops breathing. Correct approach: 10mg IV slowly, wait 5 minutes, assess effect, give second 10mg if needed. Monitor RR continuously.

common_errors.error: Didn't recognize treatment failure when seizure recurred
common_errors.teaching_point: If seizure stops briefly then RECURS without patient regaining consciousness, this is TREATMENT FAILURE. Possibilities: (1) Hypoglycemia not fully corrected (check glucose again, give more glucose), (2) Inadequate benzodiazepine dose (gave 5mg instead of 10mg), (3) Benzodiazepine wearing off before underlying cause treated. Action: Reassess glucose, give additional glucose if needed, give second dose benzodiazepine (max 20mg total). Don't assume 'well the seizure stopped once, my job is done.' Recurrent seizure = ongoing emergency requiring escalation.

common_errors.error: Panicked about postictal confusion, considered it complication requiring more treatment
common_errors.teaching_point: Postictal confusion is NORMAL after seizure. Patient will be drowsy, confused, disoriented for 10-30 minutes after seizure stops. This is brain recovering from massive neuronal discharge. It's EXPECTED, not a complication. The key is: consciousness GRADUALLY IMPROVES (GCS 6→10→12→14-15 over 10-20 minutes). If improving = normal. If staying GCS 3 or worsening = problem. Don't give more sedation, don't panic, don't call for helicopter. Just monitor, support, reassure family, transport for evaluation. Distinguish normal recovery from pathological ongoing decreased consciousness.

common_errors.error: Didn't flush IV after concentrated glucose administration
common_errors.teaching_point: Glucose 40% is concentrated, irritating solution. MUST flush IV with normal saline after giving glucose to prevent vein irritation and thrombophlebitis. This is good IV technique and prevents complications. Small detail but important for patient comfort and vein preservation.

common_errors.error: Gave excessive IV fluids during seizure (large boluses)
common_errors.teaching_point: Patient is not volume depleted (normal BP 155/92). Large IV fluid boluses not needed and may cause fluid overload. IV access is for glucose and benzodiazepine administration, not volume resuscitation. Keep IV patent with KVO (keep vein open) rate or small flushes. Don't give 500ml or 1000ml boluses unless patient actually hypotensive (not this case).

common_errors.error: Delayed treatment while performing extensive head-to-toe examination
common_errors.teaching_point: Status epilepticus is TRUE EMERGENCY - brain is being damaged every minute seizure continues. Do NOT delay critical interventions (oxygen, glucose check, glucose administration, benzodiazepine) for complete systematic examination. Sequence: (1) Airway/positioning, (2) Oxygen, (3) Check glucose, (4) Treat glucose/seizure, THEN (5) Complete assessment during transport or after seizure stopped. Time = brain. Front-load the critical treatments, complete detailed exam later.

common_errors.error: Didn't ask about insulin use / didn't put together diabetes + didn't eat + took insulin = hypoglycemia
common_errors.teaching_point: Critical history-taking failure. The key pieces were: (1) Type 1 diabetic, (2) Didn't eat yesterday/today, (3) Took insulin last night, (4) Felt 'shaky and weak' this morning (hypoglycemia symptoms). Put these together = HYPOGLYCEMIA causing seizure. This is why history matters. Ask: 'When did she last eat? Did she take her insulin?' These questions give you the diagnosis before you even check glucose. Develop pattern recognition: diabetic + didn't eat + took insulin = hypoglycemia. Check glucose immediately.

common_errors.error: Didn't provide boyfriend with education about hypoglycemia prevention
common_errors.teaching_point: Educational moment: Explain to boyfriend that this seizure happened because blood sugar got too low (she took insulin but didn't eat enough). Teach: 'If she's sick and not eating, she needs to reduce her insulin dose or eat small amounts frequently. The insulin keeps working even if she's not eating, which can cause dangerously low blood sugar. If she ever feels shaky, sweaty, or weak like she did this morning, that's low blood sugar - she should check her glucose and eat/drink something sweet immediately. That feeling is a warning sign.' Preventing future emergencies through education is part of good prehospital care.

aar_teaching_points.title: WHY is patient seizing? - Treating cause vs suppressing symptoms
aar_teaching_points.key_concept: Always ask 'why is this happening?' before reflexively treating symptoms. In this case: Type 1 diabetic + didn't eat + took insulin = HYPOGLYCEMIA → seizure. Treating hypoglycemia (glucose IV) stops seizure by fixing the cause. Treating with benzodiazepine alone suppresses symptom without fixing cause → longer recovery, risk of recurrence. VITAMINS mnemonic for seizure causes: Vascular, Infection, Trauma, Aura (epilepsy), Metabolic (HYPOGLYCEMIA), Iatrogenic, Neoplasm, Syncope.
aar_teaching_points.clinical_impact: Checking glucose takes 30 seconds. Giving glucose (if low) stops seizure in 2-4 minutes. This is faster and safer than benzodiazepine-only approach. Plus you've fixed the underlying problem. This is the essence of emergency medicine: diagnose and treat the cause when possible, not just manage symptoms.
aar_teaching_points.evidence: Hypoglycemia <3.0 mmol/L causes seizures in diabetics. Glucose administration terminates hypoglycemic seizures more rapidly than benzodiazepines alone. Always check glucose in altered mental status or seizures.

aar_teaching_points.title: Benzodiazepine dose titration - balance efficacy vs respiratory depression
aar_teaching_points.key_concept: Status epilepticus requires adequate benzodiazepine dosing but respiratory depression is major risk. Standard dose: 10mg IV diazepam, may repeat 10mg after 5-10 min (max 20mg prehospital). Too little (5mg) = seizure continues. Too much (>20mg or given too rapidly) = respiratory depression, requires BVM. The skill: titrate to effect. Give 10mg, wait 5 minutes, assess, give second 10mg if needed. Monitor RR continuously. Have BVM ready.
aar_teaching_points.clinical_impact: Under-dosing prolongs seizure → brain damage continues. Over-dosing causes respiratory failure → hypoxic brain damage. The goal is 'just right' - enough to stop seizure, not so much patient stops breathing. This requires clinical judgment and continuous monitoring.
aar_teaching_points.evidence: Diazepam 10mg IV is standard first-line for status epilepticus. Doses >20mg increase respiratory depression risk significantly. Slow administration (5mg/min) reduces cardiovascular side effects.

aar_teaching_points.title: Airway management during seizures - what NOT to do
aar_teaching_points.key_concept: NEVER force oral airway (or anything) into seizing patient's mouth. Jaw clenched during tonic-clonic seizure - physically impossible and dangerous to force OPA. Causes broken teeth, jaw injury, equipment damage. Correct approach: position on side (recovery position), suction accessible secretions, high-flow oxygen, have BVM ready. Insert OPA AFTER seizure stops if needed. Also: never restrain seizing patient - increases injury risk.
aar_teaching_points.clinical_impact: Forcing airways during seizures is classic preventable error causing iatrogenic injuries. Proper positioning and oxygenation protect airway adequately during seizure without dangerous interventions. Demonstrates understanding of 'first do no harm.'
aar_teaching_points.evidence: Positioning in recovery position during seizures reduces aspiration risk. Attempting oral airway insertion during active seizure with clenched jaw causes high rate of dental trauma and soft tissue injury. Current guidelines recommend positioning and oxygenation, not forced airway devices.

aar_teaching_points.title: Postictal state - normal recovery vs pathological findings
aar_teaching_points.key_concept: Postictal confusion is NORMAL after seizures - not a complication. Patient will be drowsy, confused, disoriented for 10-30 minutes. This is brain 'rebooting' after neuronal discharge. Key differentiator: TREND. Normal = GCS gradually improves (6→10→12→14-15). Abnormal = GCS stays 3 or worsens. If treated appropriately (glucose corrected, seizure stopped), patient will wake - give it time. Don't over-treat normal recovery.
aar_teaching_points.clinical_impact: Recognizing postictal state prevents unnecessary interventions (more sedation, calling for helicopter, panicking). Provides appropriate reassurance to family. Distinguishes normal recovery from ongoing pathology. This is pattern recognition - learn the classic presentation.
aar_teaching_points.evidence: Postictal state typically lasts 10-30 minutes after generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Duration and severity correlate with seizure duration. Gradual improvement expected. Failure to improve or deterioration suggests complications.

aar_teaching_points.title: Status epilepticus is time-critical emergency - front-load interventions
aar_teaching_points.key_concept: Status epilepticus causes permanent brain damage if >30 minutes total duration. Every minute counts. Do NOT delay critical treatments for complete examination. Sequence: (1) Position/airway (30 sec), (2) Oxygen (30 sec), (3) Check glucose (30 sec), (4) Give glucose if <3.5 (1 min), (5) Give benzodiazepine if seizure continues (2 min). Total: <5 minutes to definitive treatment. Complete detailed assessment during transport or after seizure stopped.
aar_teaching_points.clinical_impact: Delayed treatment = prolonged seizure = worse neurological outcomes. Time = brain. Students often want to do systematic head-to-toe before treating - this is wrong in status epilepticus. Front-load the critical interventions, complete assessment later.
aar_teaching_points.evidence: Status epilepticus >30 minutes causes permanent neurological injury. Mortality increases with duration. Guidelines emphasize rapid treatment - benzodiazepines within 5 minutes, second-line agents by 20 minutes if refractory. Prehospital goal: glucose check and treatment within 2 minutes, benzodiazepine within 5 minutes.
